Hate to say it, but I believe this is the first SciShow video I’ve ever had any disagreement with.

Relative humidity IS indeed the ideal measurement for how the air feels, or affects us or our belongings. Whether in reference to whether your skin feels moist or dry, or whether your wooden floors, cabinet, or guitar might swell up or dry out and crack, this is all directly relative to relative humidity. The absolute volume of moisture in the air is effectively irrelevant. What makes the difference is how ready the air is (based on moisture content vs temperature, I.e., relative humidity) to absorb or release moisture.

A wood panel will maintain (almost) the exact same moisture content and dimensions at 50% humidity at 85°F, as it will at 40°F. Same goes for your skin.

The problem is not that relative humidity is a bad unit to gauge by, but rather that meteorological reports list the OUTSIDE relative humidity. When it’s 75% outside in winter at 30°, but then you warm that air to 70° Indoors, it becomes terribly (relatively) dry. Likewise, when it’s 60% humidity outdoors in summer at 85°, and that air sinks down to your cool basement, the same amount of moisture leads to a very high relative humidity, resulting in the notoriously damp basement.

So I would argue that relative humidity is indeed the more practical and useful reference, with little importance on dew point or total moisture content as any kind of useful metric for general use. You just have to be looking at the relative humidity in the environment of concern, not looking at outdoor humidity as gauge to the health of your piano or violin which is indoors.

This description wasn't very good TBH. If the air has 25% remaining capacity for water, it isn't going to feel THAT sticky at all either way, as there is still room for your sweat to evaporate and cool you. The problem is that when we talk about feeling "dry" in colder weather, we are usually in artificially warmed environments, such as indoors. Thus, the air being fed indoors from outside has low absolute humidity and is being warmed, such that even if the relative humidity outdoors is 75%, indoors (once that same air is warmed) will have a relative humidity of more like 40%. THAT is why if feels so much dryer in the winter. If you were outside where the air was 75% relatively humid, it would not feel that dry. You would just be cold. But since you are cold, you aren't sweating a lot either, and thus there is little excess precipitation on your skin to make you feel "sticky".

It gets more confusing if you want to estimate if that relative humidity will dry a solid, like grain, that isn't necessary the same temperature.  The solid has in a different relative humidity in effect.

Well, since this video was disappointing, I will share something I only wrapped my brain around recently.

Relative humidity is the ratio between the current partial pressure of gaseous water and the vapour pressure of water at that temperature. It really has nothing to do with the air, other than its temperature, and the air doesn’t really “hold” water.

Partial pressure is like this: If I have a gas mixture of 80% nitrogen and 20% oxygen, and the pressure of that gas is 1 bar, then partial pressure of the nitrogen is 0.8 bar, and the partial pressure of the oxygen is 0.2 bar.

Vapour pressure is like this: I take a gas bottle and pump everything out of it so it is a complete vacuum, then I add some water to it. Some of the water will stay as a liquid, and some will turn into a gas. The pressure of the gas at a given temperature is the vapour pressure. If I heat up the gas bottle, the liquid water will boil, the vapour pressure will increase and there will be more water as gas and less water as liquid. (this is how heat pipes work btw)

The vapour pressure of water is pretty low, 23.388 millibar at 20C. If the partial pressure of the water vapour in 20C air was 23.388 mbar, the humidity would be 100%. If the partial pressure of the water vapour in 20C air was 11.694 mbar, the humidity would be 50%.
